instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, USB supply (<CHIP>U4600</CHIP>) burned -> replaced now short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> HOT!
threads.message:
Hi guys,

this one had an exploded <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> when it arrived (it smoked while the customer was testing it) and I replaced it with new one and the short seems to be gone.

now when I turn it on the fans start and stop after 1-2 secs OR can last upto 10sec - this is when I noticed that <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> gets REALLY hot and by measuring around I got a diode mode reading on 0,018 on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>. Of course I have no <SIGNAL>PP1V5_GPU_REG</SIGNAL> and I measure 0V on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>, too.

I see <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is generated by <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR>, should I remove that and inject 5V with a power supply to see what gets hot? (there is also <CAPACITOR>C7860</CAPACITOR> there which I may also have to remove just incase it shorts).

Should I replace <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> first? Since it gets hot maybe thats the one shorted to ground?

Where would you start?

Please advise :)


BR,
george

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, USB supply (<CHIP>U4600</CHIP>) burned -> replaced now short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> HOT!
threads.message: Surge on 5V bus, there may be lots of damage. Start with <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> and go from there. Usually <CHIP>U4800</CHIP> is the first one to die, check <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> for low resistance too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, USB supply (<CHIP>U4600</CHIP>) burned -> replaced now short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> HOT!
threads.message:
ok duke I will replace <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> today and let you know..

diode mode to ground for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is 0,381 when it was close to zero before <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> replacement. Resistance between GND and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is approx. 16.3Kohm.

<CHIP>U4800</CHIP> is important for what? I see  "IR Support" as title in the schematic..  or you mean it could also short?

george

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, USB supply (<CHIP>U4600</CHIP>) burned -> replaced now short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> HOT!
threads.message:
update: I removed <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> which was getting very hot but measuring <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C9501</CAPACITOR> gives 0.023 diode mode. This means the short is present elsewhere on this rail but was also somehow affecting <CHIP>U9500</CHIP>.

should I inject 5V now? You see me reluctant because I would really like to follow the correct procedure with this one without "sudden moves" ...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, USB supply (<CHIP>U4600</CHIP>) burned -> replaced now short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <CHIP>U9500</CHIP> HOT!
threads.message: Yeah inject 5V and see what heats up, but this board will have extensive damage. Probably 50% of chips on <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> bus are dead, starting with all the ISL chips.
